According to a recent report by UBS, the multinational investment bank, the current global geopolitical climate is the top concern for Asia family offices. The second and third largest concerns were noted as market volatility and geopolitics in Asia, respectively.
This report is based on a survey of 70 family offices across Asia. The results show that these offices are increasingly worried about how the global geopolitical climate will impact their investments. This includes concerns about rising tensions between the US and China, as well as the unpredictability of other global actors such as North Korea, Russia, and the Middle East.
These worries are not surprising given the current state of the world. However, what is interesting is the potential impact this could have on investment strategies. Family offices are taking an increasingly cautious approach, with a focus on diversification and risk management. For example, some are looking to alternative investments such as private equity and real estate to mitigate risk while still achieving growth.
One example of a family office that is taking this approach is the Chinachem Group, a Hong Kong-based property development firm. According to a recent interview with the South China Morning Post, the company plans to expand its real estate portfolio in Europe over the next few years. This move is seen as a way to diversify their investments and mitigate the risks associated with the current geopolitical climate.
Another example comes from the Taipei-based Cathay Financial Holdings, which has increased its holdings of private equity and real estate as a result of concerns about market volatility. According to a recent interview with the Taiwan News, the company is also looking to expand its alternative investments into areas such as infrastructure and renewable energy.

As the world economies are struggling to keep pace with the pandemic, Asian equities have emerged as a resilient market, drawing global money in large quantities. According to Bloomberg, over $5 billion flowed into Asian equity funds in the month of March only, and it is still rising. This trend is fueled by the fear of China's continued crackdown on its tech giants and the overall investment climate.
The Chinese Communist Party's crackdown on the country's technology giants has led to widespread concern among the global investors, signaling an uncertain future for China's tech sector. The government crackdown on Alibaba, Ant Group, DiDi, and several other companies has dented the tech giants' stock prices, prompting a flight of funds out of China and into Asian markets. This trend is not going to be relief anytime soon, as China's crackdown is expected to continue, with financial and tech regulations becoming even stricter.
As a result of China's crackdown on tech giants, investors are becoming wary of investing in China and are increasingly looking to diversify their portfolios and find alternative investment opportunities. The Asian market has become an attractive proposition, and investors are focusing their attention on Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and India. The Japanese equity market, for instance, has been on fire, with the Nikkei Stock Average surging over 20% year-to-date.
The South Korean market is another highlight of the region, as its tech conglomerates such as Samsung, LG, and SK Hynix are enjoying a bullish run, with global investors pouring money into these stocks. Taiwan and India are also witnessing a surge in foreign investment and are touted as the emerging hubs for manufacturing and technology.
The uncertain future of China's economy and trade disputes between China and countries like the USA only add to the skepticism that investors have about pouring vast sums into the emerging markets. As the world economy continues to navigate through the pandemic and its after-effects, the focus is expected to remain on Asia at least for the foreseeable future.

It was supposed to be a covert relationship that would help the US ally Pakistan gain the upper hand in the war against terrorism. Pakistan had long been suffering from the spillover effects of the terrorist activities in its neighbourhood and had sought US and global support in its fight against terrorism. However, Pakistan's decision to play a double game ended up being a nightmare, ultimately resulting in the rise of the very extremist groups it had sought to silence.
One of the main examples of Pakistan's covert support for the Taliban was through its intelligence agency, the ISI, which provided training, intelligence, and even funds to the extremist group. The ISI was using the Taliban as a proxy in its regional power struggle with India, which was supporting the Northern Alliance in Afghanistan.
This covert relationship resulted in years of violence and bloodshed in Afghanistan, and the rise of extremist groups that went on to threaten Pakistan's own security. The US, which had been a key ally of Pakistan, ultimately had to step in and take action against Bin Laden and other terrorists hiding in Pakistan, leading to a strain in the relationship between the two countries.
Furthermore, Pakistan's support for the Taliban was directly responsible for the rise of the Pakistani Taliban, a faction that goes against the Pakistani state and government, and has carried out numerous deadly attacks, including the infamous attack on a school in Peshawar in 2014, which killed more than 140 people, most of them children.
One of the most striking examples of how Pakistan's support for the Taliban backfired is the case of Malala Yousafzai, the young activist who defied the Taliban's ban on education for girls and was shot in the head. The Taliban's violent actions against Malala sparked a global outcry and forced Pakistan to confront its own role in supporting extremist groups.

The bank manager tried to reason with them, but they were ruthless and would not budge. The backlash was swift and brutal. The Taliban fighters, emboldened by their new-found power and influence, began to launch attacks not only on Pakistan's enemies, but also on Pakistan itself.

It was a sunny day when Mohammad, a small businessman in Peshawar, Pakistan, got a phone call from his boss. He was instructed to shut down his small electronics store on the crowded market street and evacuate the area immediately. Confused, he asked for the reason, but his boss didn't give any explanation and hung up the phone. Later that day, Mohammad learned that a suicide bomber had detonated an explosive device just a few blocks away, killing and injuring dozens of people.
Such incidents were unfortunately common in Pakistan during the late 2000s and early 2010s, when the country was grappling with a wave of terrorism that claimed thousands of lives and cost billions of dollars in losses. At the time, the Taliban - a radical Islamic group that ruled Afghanistan from 1996 to 2001 - had regrouped in the tribal areas along Pakistan's border, using the ungoverned territory as a launchpad for attacks on both Pakistan and Afghanistan, as well as planning international terrorist plots.
While Pakistan officially opposed the Taliban, its intelligence agency, the Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), secretly maintained a relationship with the group, hoping to exert influence in Afghanistan and protect its own interests. However, this strategy backfired in many ways and turned into a liability for Pakistan's economy and international relations.
Pakistan's relationship with the Taliban resulted in a vicious cycle of violence that took a heavy toll on its citizens, businesses, and government. According to estimates by the Global Terrorism Database, Pakistan experienced more than 41,000 terrorist attacks between 2001 and 2018, resulting in over 74,000 deaths and 123,000 injuries. The attacks targeted a wide range of targets, from military and police installations to religious sites, marketplaces, schools, hospitals, and public transport.
The attacks had a significant impact on Pakistan's economy, as they scared away foreign investors, disrupted trade, and caused widespread damage to infrastructure and property. The Pakistan Institute of Development Economics estimated in 2017 that the cumulative economic cost of terrorism from 2000 to 2017 was about $126 billion, or around 6% of the country's GDP. The report also noted that the terrorist violence had reduced the lifespan of an average Pakistani citizen by about five years.

Meet Rachel. She is a college student who started suffering from an eating disorder. She was in denial and didn't talk to anyone about it until she discovered an AI chatbot named "S.H.E", which stands for Support, Help, and Encouragement. It's an AI chatbot developed by the National Eating Disorder Association (NEDA) with the aim of helping people who suffer from eating disorders. Rachel was hesitant to use the chatbot, but eventually, she did, and that was the turning point for her.
S.H.E uses artificial intelligence to provide users with intelligent and personalized conversations through messaging. It can communicate in a friendly and empathetic way with different methods, such as relaxation techniques for various problems related to eating disorders, including anorexia, bulimia, and binge-eating disorder. S.H.E is available 24/7, and users can access it from their mobile phones, which is convenient for people who need an immediate response, like Rachel.
Rachel found S.H.E to be a useful tool for anonymous communication to discuss her eating disorder-related issues without any fear of judgment. Moreover, the chatbot provided helpful information and resources on how to manage and overcome an eating disorder and assisted with connecting with health professionals. With S.H.E, Rachel felt safe and empowered to take control of her life.
Rachel's story is not unique. According to the National Institute of Mental Health, an estimated 9% of the U.S. population will experience an eating disorder in their lifetime, and individuals with eating disorders are more likely to have other mental health conditions or be at risk of suicide. Early intervention and treatment can significantly improve outcomes, and NEDA's S.H.E chatbot offers much-needed support.
NEDA reports that the S.H.E chatbot has already helped hundreds of thousands of people in its two-year history. An internal NEDA survey revealed that 93% of people who used it reported the chatbot was helpful, and 87% said they would recommend it to a friend. Among the survey's respondents, 81% disclosed that they had never sought treatment before using the S.H.E chatbox, which shows the benefit of using technology to encourage early intervention.

It was a typical workday for Dr. Maria, a primary health care worker in a rural village in the Philippines until a pandemic hit. Back then, the virus was only a distant threat, and she didn't think much of it. But within months, the situation had changed. Her village was one of the many in the country that had been infected by the disease. With her limited resources, Dr. Maria had to work around the clock to ensure that her community received the care they needed.
Dr. Maria's story is not unique. Primary health care workers around the world have been working tirelessly to keep their communities safe in the face of pandemics. However, the COVID-19 pandemic has shown us that primary health care systems need more investment and support to ensure that they can provide effective pandemic response.
Investments in primary health care can lead to better pandemic preparedness. By improving primary health care systems, countries can detect and respond to outbreaks faster, reducing the risk of pandemics spreading.
For example, in 2018, Nigeria launched an electronic disease surveillance system to improve disease detection and outbreak response. The system, which was developed with support from the World Bank, includes a mobile application that allows health care workers to report suspected cases and receive alerts on potential outbreaks. Since its launch, the system has helped Nigeria respond to various disease outbreaks, including a meningitis outbreak in 2018.
Primary health care investment has also led to improvements in health care service delivery.
